__label__fake 
__label__fake 經查：
__label__fake 該影片2018年7月已在網路上流傳，事件地點為南印度，一名男子疑似喝醉酒而意外觸電身亡，與此次新冠疫情隔離措施無關。
__label__fake 因此，此傳言為挪用印度的意外事件影片，後製加上不實文字的「錯誤」訊息。
__label__fake 近期通訊軟體流傳一支影片，長度47秒。影片中男子站在屋頂，主動觸碰高壓電線，因而觸電墜樓。畫面壓上中文字：「他不想再等14天。」，暗指男子做出這個舉動，與此次新冠疫情的14天隔離措施有關。
__label__fake 
__label__fake 圖1：網傳影片擷圖
__label__fake 爭議點、網傳影片來源為何？與新冠疫情隔離措施有關嗎？
__label__fake （一）查核中心以影片擷圖反搜，找到網路上印度文、波斯文、日文、英文等多種語言的版本，影片上傳時間為2018年7月中旬。
__label__fake 
__label__fake 圖2、3、4：網路相同影片擷圖
__label__fake 經比對，其它影片的畫面內容、長度，均與網傳影片相同，但並未壓上「他不想再等14天。」字樣。
__label__fake 
__label__fake 
__label__fake 圖5、6：網傳影片與YouTube影片比對／台灣事實查核中心製圖
__label__fake （二）印度查核組織《Boom》查核記者Karen Rebelo協助查證。Karen Rebelo指出，影片中人物所講的語言是南印度的卡納達語 （Karnataka），底下的人們對著穿白色衣服的男人叫喊，讓他遠離高壓電線。
__label__fake Karen協助搜尋此事件的相關新聞，其中，《Indian Express》2018年7月7日報導指出，該事件發生在印度泰米爾那都州，一名沉迷於酒精的男子RajuT，在酒醉後爬上四層樓高的建築物，並用雙手握住高壓電線，導致觸電死亡。
__label__fake 另一則《今日印度》2018年7月13日報導指出，影片中男子在屋頂上，張開雙臂握住上方的電線，並不理會底下圍觀人群的喊叫阻止。該男子在觸碰到高壓電線時，就因觸電而身亡。
__label__fake 綜合以上，該影片在2018年7月已在網路上流傳，地點為南印度，男子疑似喝醉酒而意外觸電身亡，與此次新冠疫情隔離措施無關。
__label__fake 網傳影片2018年7月已在網路上流傳，事件地點為南印度，一名男子疑似喝醉酒而意外觸電身亡，與此次新冠疫情隔離措施無關。
__label__fake 因此，此傳言為挪用印度意外事件影片，後製加上不實文字的「錯誤」訊息。
__label__fake Indian Express〈Drunk man grabs power line, dies of electrocution〉
__label__fake India Today〈Shocking! Man dies after touching high-tension wire〉
__label__fake 
__label__fake Las cadenas de mensajes engañosos circulan, principalmente, vía WhatsApp. Fuente: Reproducción.
__label__fake ‌‌
__label__fake ‌
__label__fake ‌
__label__fake Es falso que la Organización Mundial de la Salud (OMS), la Organización de Naciones Unidas (ONU) y el Gobierno estén entregando bonos por la pandemia de covid-19, como aseguran mensajes que se comparten por redes sociales.
__label__fake Las informaciones falsas, que viajan principalmente vía WhatsApp, incluyen vínculos a sitios web donde los usuarios pueden ser víctimas de robo de datos personales o sus equipos pueden ser infectados con malware.
__label__fake “Se trata de una información falsa para obtener datos de las personas. Les instamos a denunciar estas páginas y no entregar ninguna información personal”, dijo la representante de la ONU en Costa Rica, Alice Shackelford.
__label__fake Previamente, #NoComaCuento alertó también sobre otras tres modalidades que están empleando los ciberdelincuentes y estafadores aprovechándose de la coyuntura generada por la emergencia del covid-19:
__label__fake - Una aplicación para teléfonos Android que ofrece un supuesto “mapeo” del avance de la pandemia por covid-19 llamada coronavirusapp.site.
__label__fake - Un mensaje falso de WhatsApp que promete regalar un bono de datos de navegación de “1.000 GB” para que las personas consuman durante la pandemia.
__label__fake - Estafas telefónicas en que se usa como excusa la moratoria tributaria propuesta por el Gobierno para mitigar los efectos adversos del covid-19.
__label__fake El director de gobernanza digital del Ministerio de Ciencia, Tecnología y Telecomunicaciones, Jorge Mora, brindó una serie de recomendaciones para evitar ser víctima del cibercrimen:
__label__fake - Si se recibe un correo electrónico ofreciendo dinero o información acerca del covid-19 y en este correo se les solicita descargar algún archivo, por favor no lo hagan y eliminen el correo.
__label__fake - Si se ingresa a una página web, hay que estar seguros que esa página cuente con un certificado de seguridad o que sea un sitio seguro; esto se puede ver en el navegador con la figura de un candado o en la barra superior, donde se muestra que la dirección de la página inicia con las letras https.
__label__fake - Por lo general, los medios oficiales nunca solicitan que se descargue una aplicación para poder mostrarnos información.
__label__fake - Cuando se descargan las apps en los celulares, se recomienda hacerlo por medio de tiendas oficiales como el AppStore o Google Play, y nunca realizarlo desde una página web.
__label__fake - Finalmente, siempre se tiene que verificar tanto que el desarrollador de la aplicación o que la página web que estemos visitando, sean fuentes oficiales y reconocidas, tal como un ministerio o una organización internacional.
__label__fake LEA MÁS: #NoComaCuento: Masxmenos de Novacentro no tiene empleados enfermos de nuevo coronavirus ni fue clausurado
__label__fake Esta información forma parte del proyecto #NoComaCuento, una iniciativa de La Nación que busca analizar la veracidad de la información que circula en redes sociales. Usted puede formar parte de este proyecto enviándonos información que le parezca falsa o poco confiable al WhatsApp 6420-7160 o al correo nocomacuento@nacion.com.
__label__fake También puede recibir nuestras publicaciones directamente en su celular uniéndose a este grupo de WhatsApp o al bot de Telegram.
__label__fake En beneficio de la transparencia y para evitar distorsiones del debate público por medios informáticos o aprovechando el anonimato, la sección de comentarios está reservada para nuestros suscriptores para comentar sobre el contenido de los artículos, no sobre los autores. El nombre completo y número de cédula del suscriptor aparecerá automáticamente con el comentario.
__label__fake © 2024 Todos los derechos reservados, cualquier uso requiere autorización expresa y por escrito de Grupo Nación GN S.A.
__label__fake © 2024 Todos los derechos reservados, cualquier uso requiere autorización expresa y por escrito de Grupo Nación GN S.A.
__label__fake Miembro del Grupo de Diarios América (GDA)
__label__fake 02 de Mayo de 2024
__label__fake 
__label__fake Falso
__label__fake Falso
__label__fake Falso
__label__fake Falso
__label__fake Falso
__label__fake Falso
__label__fake Falso
__label__fake Falso
__label__fake 
__label__fake 
__label__fake Falso
__label__fake 
__label__fake En Twitter comenzó a moverse un pantallazo en el que se ve una nota de Noticias Caracol, supuestamente sucedida en Soledad, Atlántico, con el titular "Primer Niño registrado como Yair coronavirus Mosquera". Sin embargo, Caracol no ha reportado esta noticia y no hay un niño bautizado con ese nombre en el país.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Primero, el uso errático de las mayúsculas y de una fuente diferente a la usual de Caracol en el titular hace sospechar que se trata de un montaje.
__label__fake Para comprobarlo, hicimos una búsqueda inversa de imágenes en Google, con la que encontramos la noticia original de Caracol:
__label__fake La nota fue publicada en YouTube el 22 de septiembre de 2017 con el titular "Mujer que había perdido un bebé raptó a recién nacida en un hospital" y el título en pantalla "Rescatan a bebé raptada". La noticia, realmente, contaba la historia de cómo la Policía de Soledad rescató a una bebé que había sido robada por una mujer de la zona.
__label__fake Al minuto 1:15 del video se ve, con el título original, la misma toma que fue usada para el montaje.
__label__fake 
__label__fake También buscamos en Google el nombre "Yair Coronavirus Mosquera" y no encontramos resultados.
__label__fake Por otra parte, como lo hicimos para el chequeo "Es falso que hayan bautizado a un colombiano como ‘Netflix de Jesús’", buscamos el registro civil en el buscador de la Registraduría.
__label__fake Hicimos varias búsquedas por el registro civil de una persona llamada "Yair Coronavirus Mosquera" (con fecha de nacimiento entre el 5 y el 12 de marzo de 2020), pero no encontramos nada.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Así que es falso tanto que en Colombia un niño haya sido bautizado como "Yair Coronavirus Mosquera", como que Noticias Caracol lo haya reportado.
__label__fake Un proyecto de
__label__fake Contáctanos
__label__fake Boletín
__label__fake Metodología
__label__fake 2016 - 2024 © Derechos reservados
__label__fake El Ministerio de Trabajo precisó que los depósitos del bono Proteger no se programan de acuerdo con los números de cédula, sino a partir de la fecha en la que cada beneficiario recibió la ayuda por primera vez. Foto: Reproducción.
__label__fake ‌‌
__label__fake ‌
__label__fake ‌
__label__fake Una imagen que circula vía WhatsApp divulga información falsa sobre las fechas en las que, supuestamente, se depositará el bono Proteger.
__label__fake El jefe de prensa del Ministerio de Trabajo, Geovanny Díaz, confirmó que la imagen es un montaje y contiene información incorrecta.
__label__fake Según el montaje, los beneficiarios del bono recibirían las ayudas entre el lunes y el miércoles de esta semana, según el número en el que terminan sus cédulas.
__label__fake Díaz explicó que los depósitos del bono Proteger no se programan de acuerdo con los números de cédula, sino a partir de la fecha en la que cada beneficiario recibió la ayuda por primera vez.
__label__fake “Lo que aparece en esa imagen es completamente falso, no se están programando los pagos de acuerdo a las terminaciones del número de cédula, sino que tienen que ver específicamente con la fecha en la que les fue depositado el primer bono”, comunicó el vocero de Trabajo.
__label__fake La imagen emplea los logos de Casa Presidencial, el Instituto Mixto de Ayuda Social (IMAS) y el Ministerio de Trabajo.
__label__fake Proteger es un aporte de entre ¢62.500 y ¢125.000 que gira el Gobierno a personas cuyos ingresos han caído a causa de las medidas sanitarias implementadas para contener la propagación del nuevo coronavirus.
__label__fake LEA MÁS: #NoComaCuento: Besos y abrazos sí incrementan riesgo de contagio de covid-19
__label__fake Esta información forma parte del proyecto #NoComaCuento, una iniciativa de La Nación que busca analizar la veracidad de la información que circula en redes sociales. Usted puede formar parte de este proyecto enviándonos información que le parezca falsa o poco confiable al WhatsApp 6420-7160 o al correo nocomacuento@nacion.com.
__label__fake También puede recibir nuestras publicaciones directamente en su celular uniéndose a este grupo de WhatsApp o al bot de Telegram.
__label__fake Periodista en la sección de Política. Graduada de la carrera de Ciencias de la Comunicación Colectiva con énfasis en Periodismo, en la Universidad de Costa Rica.
__label__fake En beneficio de la transparencia y para evitar distorsiones del debate público por medios informáticos o aprovechando el anonimato, la sección de comentarios está reservada para nuestros suscriptores para comentar sobre el contenido de los artículos, no sobre los autores. El nombre completo y número de cédula del suscriptor aparecerá automáticamente con el comentario.
__label__fake © 2024 Todos los derechos reservados, cualquier uso requiere autorización expresa y por escrito de Grupo Nación GN S.A.
__label__fake © 2024 Todos los derechos reservados, cualquier uso requiere autorización expresa y por escrito de Grupo Nación GN S.A.
__label__fake Miembro del Grupo de Diarios América (GDA)
__label__fake 
__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.
__label__fake

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake 
__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake 
__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.
__label__fake

__label__fake 
__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake

__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.
__label__fake

__label__fake 
__label__fake 
__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake 
__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.

__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.

__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.

__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake

__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.
__label__fake

__label__fake 
__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake 
__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake

__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.

__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.
__label__fake
