__label__fake 
__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake 
__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake

__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.

__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. __label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.
__label__fake

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake 
__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake 
__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.
__label__fake

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).

__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.
__label__fake

__label__fake

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake 
__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.
__label__fake

__label__fake 
__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.
__label__fake

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake [Editorial update: 8 May, 12:15am] The article has been updated to reflect one more confirmed case at the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake –
__label__fake In a Facebook post published on 6 May, online platform Singapore States Times claimed that the community care facility for recovering and ‘early’ COVID-19 patients at Singapore Expo has now “become a cluster itself” after a third individual was confirmed as a new case on 5 May.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The post also claims that the individual is an NSF, and was one of 100 conscripts deployed from SAF Medical Corps “as Singapore ran out of nurses”.
__label__fake It goes on to mention that none of the 100 conscripts, aged between 18 and 21, have experience working in hospitals.
__label__fake In summary, there are three main claims being made in the post:
__label__fake On 5 May, the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that a 20-year-old Singaporean man who works as a nurse is the third confirmed case working in the public healthcare sector linked to the Singapore Expo community care facility.
__label__fake The three other confirmed cases from the Singapore Expo facility are a 52-year-old Singaporean woman who was a healthcare volunteer, a 34-year-old nurse employed by the Health Promotion Board, and a 43-year-old Singaporean man who worked as a radiographer.
__label__fake In spite of having four confirmed cases so far, at no point of time was the Singapore Expo community care facility declared to be a COVID-19 cluster by MOH.
__label__fake However, something interesting to think about is which factors are considered when declaring a place a ‘cluster’ in the context of COVID-19 in Singapore.
__label__fake According to this definition, a disease cluster is “an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition that is closely grouped in time and place”.
__label__fake With four confirmed cases so far, the Singapore Expo facility technically does fit that particular definition. The Grand Hyatt Hotel, boulder+ Gym, Kian Teck Dormitory, Church of Singapore (Bukit Timah), 10 Kian Teck Crescent dormitory, and The Wedding Brocade are other examples of 3-, 4-case venues that have been declared as clusters by MOH.
__label__fake We have reached out to MOH to find out the factors that make a COVID-19 cluster in Singapore, and will update the article when we get a response.
__label__fake Thus, the claim made by Singapore States Times that Singapore Expo “has become a cluster itself” is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Next, the claims that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is an NSF and that conscripts deployed to help at Singapore Expo have no hospital experience have been addressed in a Facebook post by the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF).
__label__fake 
__label__fake Clarifications Regarding Infections in Expo CCF Published by Singapore States Times on 6 May 2020 of an NSF Infected…
__label__fake Posted by Ministry of Defence, Singapore (MINDEF) on Wednesday, 6 May 2020
__label__fake In the post, MINDEF stated that the post contained “a number of errors”.
__label__fake First, MINDEF clarified that the 20-year-old Singaporean man is not a full-time NSF, but a trained nurse from a private agency.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the third confirmed case is an NSF is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake The claim that none of the national servicemen deployed by the SAF at the Singapore Expo facility have experience in hospitals was also debunked in the post.
__label__fake “This is again wrong. Some of them are doctors and medics with prior hospital experience,” MINDEF stated in the Facebook post.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that none of the national servicemen have experience in hospitals is also false.

__label__fake 
__label__fake Des  publications partagées plus de 600 fois sur Facebook affirment que le commissaire provincial de la police en ville de Kinshasa a annoncé que seules les églises certifiées par l’État seront ouvertes. C’est faux, Sylvano Kasongo Kitenge  explique à Congo Check.
__label__fake Un message posté  sur Facebook ce mardi 28 juillet 2020 et partagé plus 600 fois en moins de 24 heures  affirme que seules les églises « certifiées par l’État seront ouvertes ». Ces propos ont été attribués au commissaire provincial de la police ville de Kinshasa Sylvano Kasongo qui cite la présidence de la République de qui émane l’ordre.
__label__fake « Urgent. Sylvano Kasongo : Nous avons reçu  l’ordre de la présidence d’autoriser l’ouverture des  églises légalement connues par l’état et qui auront les documents nécessaires, seuls ces églises seront ouvertes, aujourd’hui notre pays n’évolue plus très bien à cause des églises de réveil, nous ne pouvons plus donner la responsabilité des églises à tout le monde,  seuls les gens qui ont étudiés auront  accès à cette profession de pasteurs et prophète, l’église n’est pas un endroit de commerce ! »
__label__fake Urgent. Sylvano Kasongo annonce que seuls les églises certifiées par l’état seront ouvertes , Sylvano Kasongo : Nous…
__label__fake Interrogé par Congo Check, le général Sylvano Kasongo affirme qu’il n’a jamais tenu ces propos. « Je dis ça où et quand ?  C’est du mensonge. Je n’ai jamais dit ça “, répond-t-il succinctement.
__label__fake Cette publication fausse a suivi une sortie médiatique du général Sylvano Kasongo Kitenge dans un message adressé aux habitants de la capitale de la République Démocratique du Congo lundi 27 juillet 2020. Cet officier a appelé au respect des gestes barrières et annoncé le contrôle du port des masques dès ce mardi 28 juillet. Le chef de la police de Kinshasa a également adressé un message aux églises de réveil d’adhérer aux mesures barrières dès leur réouverture.
__label__fake « Les églises qui vont commencer le 15 (août, ndlr) doivent savoir que nous devons respecter la distanciation physique, le port correcte et obligatoire des masques et la nuisance sonore. Le 15 et le 16 (août, ndlr), les églises vont commencer à recevoir les chrétiens. Elles doivent intégrer tout ce que le commandant suprême a dit sinon, ils verront la police sur son chemin ».
__label__fake 🚨🇨🇩: les églises doivent respecter les gestes barrières … En image , écoutons tous le Général Sylvano Kasongo
__label__fake En République Démocratique du Congo, le président de la République avait annoncé la réouverture des églises au 15 août 2020 après la levée de l’État d’urgence sanitaire.
__label__fake « A partir du 15 août la réouverture des églises et lieux des cultes, la reprise des mouvements migratoires inter-provinciaux, l’ouverture des ports, aéroports et frontières », avait-il déclaré le 21 juillet 2020 en direct de la chaîne nationale.
__label__fake Les églises sont fermées depuis le 19 mars 2020. La mesure avait été prise par le chef de l’État  en vue de stopper la propagation de la pandémie de Covid-19.
__label__fake Save my name, email, and website in this browser for the next time I comment.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Δ
__label__fake Des  publications partagées plus de 600 fois sur Facebook affirment que le commissaire provincial de la police en ville de Kinshasa a annoncé que seules les églises certifiées par l’État seront ouvertes. C’est faux, Sylvano Kasongo Kitenge  explique à Congo Check.
__label__fake Un message posté  sur Facebook ce mardi 28 juillet 2020 et partagé plus 600 fois en moins de 24 heures  affirme que seules les églises « certifiées par l’État seront ouvertes ». Ces propos ont été attribués au commissaire provincial de la police ville de Kinshasa Sylvano Kasongo qui cite la présidence de la République de qui émane l’ordre.
__label__fake « Urgent. Sylvano Kasongo : Nous avons reçu  l’ordre de la présidence d’autoriser l’ouverture des  églises légalement connues par l’état et qui auront les documents nécessaires, seuls ces églises seront ouvertes, aujourd’hui notre pays n’évolue plus très bien à cause des églises de réveil, nous ne pouvons plus donner la responsabilité des églises à tout le monde,  seuls les gens qui ont étudiés auront  accès à cette profession de pasteurs et prophète, l’église n’est pas un endroit de commerce ! »
__label__fake Urgent. Sylvano Kasongo annonce que seuls les églises certifiées par l’état seront ouvertes , Sylvano Kasongo : Nous…
__label__fake Interrogé par Congo Check, le général Sylvano Kasongo affirme qu’il n’a jamais tenu ces propos. « Je dis ça où et quand ?  C’est du mensonge. Je n’ai jamais dit ça “, répond-t-il succinctement.
__label__fake Cette publication fausse a suivi une sortie médiatique du général Sylvano Kasongo Kitenge dans un message adressé aux habitants de la capitale de la République Démocratique du Congo lundi 27 juillet 2020. Cet officier a appelé au respect des gestes barrières et annoncé le contrôle du port des masques dès ce mardi 28 juillet. Le chef de la police de Kinshasa a également adressé un message aux églises de réveil d’adhérer aux mesures barrières dès leur réouverture.
__label__fake « Les églises qui vont commencer le 15 (août, ndlr) doivent savoir que nous devons respecter la distanciation physique, le port correcte et obligatoire des masques et la nuisance sonore. Le 15 et le 16 (août, ndlr), les églises vont commencer à recevoir les chrétiens. Elles doivent intégrer tout ce que le commandant suprême a dit sinon, ils verront la police sur son chemin ».
__label__fake 🚨🇨🇩: les églises doivent respecter les gestes barrières … En image , écoutons tous le Général Sylvano Kasongo
__label__fake En République Démocratique du Congo, le président de la République avait annoncé la réouverture des églises au 15 août 2020 après la levée de l’État d’urgence sanitaire.
__label__fake « A partir du 15 août la réouverture des églises et lieux des cultes, la reprise des mouvements migratoires inter-provinciaux, l’ouverture des ports, aéroports et frontières », avait-il déclaré le 21 juillet 2020 en direct de la chaîne nationale.
__label__fake Les églises sont fermées depuis le 19 mars 2020. La mesure avait été prise par le chef de l’État  en vue de stopper la propagation de la pandémie de Covid-19.
__label__fake Save my name, email, and website in this browser for the next time I comment.

__label__fake Des  publications partagées plus de 600 fois sur Facebook affirment que le commissaire provincial de la police en ville de Kinshasa a annoncé que seules les églises certifiées par l’État seront ouvertes. C’est faux, Sylvano Kasongo Kitenge  explique à Congo Check.
__label__fake Un message posté  sur Facebook ce mardi 28 juillet 2020 et partagé plus 600 fois en moins de 24 heures  affirme que seules les églises « certifiées par l’État seront ouvertes ». Ces propos ont été attribués au commissaire provincial de la police ville de Kinshasa Sylvano Kasongo qui cite la présidence de la République de qui émane l’ordre.
__label__fake « Urgent. Sylvano Kasongo : Nous avons reçu  l’ordre de la présidence d’autoriser l’ouverture des  églises légalement connues par l’état et qui auront les documents nécessaires, seuls ces églises seront ouvertes, aujourd’hui notre pays n’évolue plus très bien à cause des églises de réveil, nous ne pouvons plus donner la responsabilité des églises à tout le monde,  seuls les gens qui ont étudiés auront  accès à cette profession de pasteurs et prophète, l’église n’est pas un endroit de commerce ! »
__label__fake Urgent. Sylvano Kasongo annonce que seuls les églises certifiées par l’état seront ouvertes , Sylvano Kasongo : Nous…
__label__fake Interrogé par Congo Check, le général Sylvano Kasongo affirme qu’il n’a jamais tenu ces propos. « Je dis ça où et quand ?  C’est du mensonge. Je n’ai jamais dit ça “, répond-t-il succinctement.
__label__fake Cette publication fausse a suivi une sortie médiatique du général Sylvano Kasongo Kitenge dans un message adressé aux habitants de la capitale de la République Démocratique du Congo lundi 27 juillet 2020. Cet officier a appelé au respect des gestes barrières et annoncé le contrôle du port des masques dès ce mardi 28 juillet. Le chef de la police de Kinshasa a également adressé un message aux églises de réveil d’adhérer aux mesures barrières dès leur réouverture.
__label__fake « Les églises qui vont commencer le 15 (août, ndlr) doivent savoir que nous devons respecter la distanciation physique, le port correcte et obligatoire des masques et la nuisance sonore. Le 15 et le 16 (août, ndlr), les églises vont commencer à recevoir les chrétiens. Elles doivent intégrer tout ce que le commandant suprême a dit sinon, ils verront la police sur son chemin ».

__label__fake En République Démocratique du Congo, le président de la République avait annoncé la réouverture des églises au 15 août 2020 après la levée de l’État d’urgence sanitaire.
__label__fake « A partir du 15 août la réouverture des églises et lieux des cultes, la reprise des mouvements migratoires inter-provinciaux, l’ouverture des ports, aéroports et frontières », avait-il déclaré le 21 juillet 2020 en direct de la chaîne nationale.
__label__fake Les églises sont fermées depuis le 19 mars 2020. La mesure avait été prise par le chef de l’État  en vue de stopper la propagation de la pandémie de Covid-19.

__label__fake Des  publications partagées plus de 600 fois sur Facebook affirment que le commissaire provincial de la police en ville de Kinshasa a annoncé que seules les églises certifiées par l’État seront ouvertes. C’est faux, Sylvano Kasongo Kitenge  explique à Congo Check.
__label__fake Un message posté  sur Facebook ce mardi 28 juillet 2020 et partagé plus 600 fois en moins de 24 heures  affirme que seules les églises « certifiées par l’État seront ouvertes ». Ces propos ont été attribués au commissaire provincial de la police ville de Kinshasa Sylvano Kasongo qui cite la présidence de la République de qui émane l’ordre.
__label__fake « Urgent. Sylvano Kasongo : Nous avons reçu  l’ordre de la présidence d’autoriser l’ouverture des  églises légalement connues par l’état et qui auront les documents nécessaires, seuls ces églises seront ouvertes, aujourd’hui notre pays n’évolue plus très bien à cause des églises de réveil, nous ne pouvons plus donner la responsabilité des églises à tout le monde,  seuls les gens qui ont étudiés auront  accès à cette profession de pasteurs et prophète, l’église n’est pas un endroit de commerce ! »
