__label__fake Interrogé par Congo Check, le général Sylvano Kasongo affirme qu’il n’a jamais tenu ces propos. « Je dis ça où et quand ?  C’est du mensonge. Je n’ai jamais dit ça “, répond-t-il succinctement.
__label__fake Cette publication fausse a suivi une sortie médiatique du général Sylvano Kasongo Kitenge dans un message adressé aux habitants de la capitale de la République Démocratique du Congo lundi 27 juillet 2020. Cet officier a appelé au respect des gestes barrières et annoncé le contrôle du port des masques dès ce mardi 28 juillet. Le chef de la police de Kinshasa a également adressé un message aux églises de réveil d’adhérer aux mesures barrières dès leur réouverture.
__label__fake « Les églises qui vont commencer le 15 (août, ndlr) doivent savoir que nous devons respecter la distanciation physique, le port correcte et obligatoire des masques et la nuisance sonore. Le 15 et le 16 (août, ndlr), les églises vont commencer à recevoir les chrétiens. Elles doivent intégrer tout ce que le commandant suprême a dit sinon, ils verront la police sur son chemin ».

__label__fake En République Démocratique du Congo, le président de la République avait annoncé la réouverture des églises au 15 août 2020 après la levée de l’État d’urgence sanitaire.
__label__fake « A partir du 15 août la réouverture des églises et lieux des cultes, la reprise des mouvements migratoires inter-provinciaux, l’ouverture des ports, aéroports et frontières », avait-il déclaré le 21 juillet 2020 en direct de la chaîne nationale.
__label__fake Les églises sont fermées depuis le 19 mars 2020. La mesure avait été prise par le chef de l’État  en vue de stopper la propagation de la pandémie de Covid-19.

Le 15 et le 16 (août, ndlr), les églises vont commencer à recevoir les chrétiens. Elles doivent intégrer tout ce que le commandant suprême a dit sinon, ils verront la police sur son chemin ».

__label__fake En République Démocratique du Congo, le président de la République avait annoncé la réouverture des églises au 15 août 2020 après la levée de l’État d’urgence sanitaire.
__label__fake « A partir du 15 août la réouverture des églises et lieux des cultes, la reprise des mouvements migratoires inter-provinciaux, l’ouverture des ports, aéroports et frontières », avait-il déclaré le 21 juillet 2020 en direct de la chaîne nationale.
__label__fake Les églises sont fermées depuis le 19 mars 2020. La mesure avait été prise par le chef de l’État  en vue de stopper la propagation de la pandémie de Covid-19.
__label__fake Save my name, email, and website in this browser for the next time I comment.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Δ
__label__fake Des  publications partagées plus de 600 fois sur Facebook affirment que le commissaire provincial de la police en ville de Kinshasa a annoncé que seules les églises certifiées par l’État seront ouvertes. C’est faux, Sylvano Kasongo Kitenge  explique à Congo Check.
__label__fake Un message posté  sur Facebook ce mardi 28 juillet 2020 et partagé plus 600 fois en moins de 24 heures  affirme que seules les églises « certifiées par l’État seront ouvertes ». Ces propos ont été attribués au commissaire provincial de la police ville de Kinshasa Sylvano Kasongo qui cite la présidence de la République de qui émane l’ordre.
__label__fake « Urgent. Sylvano Kasongo : Nous avons reçu  l’ordre de la présidence d’autoriser l’ouverture des  églises légalement connues par l’état et qui auront les documents nécessaires, seuls ces églises seront ouvertes, aujourd’hui notre pays n’évolue plus très bien à cause des églises de réveil, nous ne pouvons plus donner la responsabilité des églises à tout le monde,  seuls les gens qui ont étudiés auront  accès à cette profession de pasteurs et prophète, l’église n’est pas un endroit de commerce ! »
__label__fake Urgent. Sylvano Kasongo annonce que seuls les églises certifiées par l’état seront ouvertes , Sylvano Kasongo : Nous…
__label__fake Interrogé par Congo Check, le général Sylvano Kasongo affirme qu’il n’a jamais tenu ces propos. « Je dis ça où et quand ?  C’est du mensonge. Je n’ai jamais dit ça “, répond-t-il succinctement.
__label__fake Cette publication fausse a suivi une sortie médiatique du général Sylvano Kasongo Kitenge dans un message adressé aux habitants de la capitale de la République Démocratique du Congo lundi 27 juillet 2020. Cet officier a appelé au respect des gestes barrières et annoncé le contrôle du port des masques dès ce mardi 28 juillet. Le chef de la police de Kinshasa a également adressé un message aux églises de réveil d’adhérer aux mesures barrières dès leur réouverture.
__label__fake « Les églises qui vont commencer le 15 (août, ndlr) doivent savoir que nous devons respecter la distanciation physique, le port correcte et obligatoire des masques et la nuisance sonore. Le 15 et le 16 (août, ndlr), les églises vont commencer à recevoir les chrétiens. Elles doivent intégrer tout ce que le commandant suprême a dit sinon, ils verront la police sur son chemin ».
__label__fake 🚨🇨🇩: les églises doivent respecter les gestes barrières … En image , écoutons tous le Général Sylvano Kasongo
__label__fake En République Démocratique du Congo, le président de la République avait annoncé la réouverture des églises au 15 août 2020 après la levée de l’État d’urgence sanitaire.
__label__fake « A partir du 15 août la réouverture des églises et lieux des cultes, la reprise des mouvements migratoires inter-provinciaux, l’ouverture des ports, aéroports et frontières », avait-il déclaré le 21 juillet 2020 en direct de la chaîne nationale.
__label__fake Les églises sont fermées depuis le 19 mars 2020. La mesure avait été prise par le chef de l’État  en vue de stopper la propagation de la pandémie de Covid-19.
__label__fake Save my name, email, and website in this browser for the next time I comment.

__label__fake Δ
__label__fake Des  publications partagées plus de 600 fois sur Facebook affirment que le commissaire provincial de la police en ville de Kinshasa a annoncé que seules les églises certifiées par l’État seront ouvertes. C’est faux, Sylvano Kasongo Kitenge  explique à Congo Check.
__label__fake Un message posté  sur Facebook ce mardi 28 juillet 2020 et partagé plus 600 fois en moins de 24 heures  affirme que seules les églises « certifiées par l’État seront ouvertes ». Ces propos ont été attribués au commissaire provincial de la police ville de Kinshasa Sylvano Kasongo qui cite la présidence de la République de qui émane l’ordre.
__label__fake « Urgent. Sylvano Kasongo : Nous avons reçu  l’ordre de la présidence d’autoriser l’ouverture des  églises légalement connues par l’état et qui auront les documents nécessaires, seuls ces églises seront ouvertes, aujourd’hui notre pays n’évolue plus très bien à cause des églises de réveil, nous ne pouvons plus donner la responsabilité des églises à tout le monde,  seuls les gens qui ont étudiés auront  accès à cette profession de pasteurs et prophète, l’église n’est pas un endroit de commerce ! »
__label__fake Urgent. Sylvano Kasongo annonce que seuls les églises certifiées par l’état seront ouvertes , Sylvano Kasongo : Nous…
__label__fake Interrogé par Congo Check, le général Sylvano Kasongo affirme qu’il n’a jamais tenu ces propos. « Je dis ça où et quand ?  C’est du mensonge. Je n’ai jamais dit ça “, répond-t-il succinctement.
__label__fake Cette publication fausse a suivi une sortie médiatique du général Sylvano Kasongo Kitenge dans un message adressé aux habitants de la capitale de la République Démocratique du Congo lundi 27 juillet 2020. Cet officier a appelé au respect des gestes barrières et annoncé le contrôle du port des masques dès ce mardi 28 juillet. Le chef de la police de Kinshasa a également adressé un message aux églises de réveil d’adhérer aux mesures barrières dès leur réouverture.
__label__fake « Les églises qui vont commencer le 15 (août, ndlr) doivent savoir que nous devons respecter la distanciation physique, le port correcte et obligatoire des masques et la nuisance sonore. Le 15 et le 16 (août, ndlr), les églises vont commencer à recevoir les chrétiens. Elles doivent intégrer tout ce que le commandant suprême a dit sinon, ils verront la police sur son chemin ».

__label__fake You can republish the text of this article free of charge, both online and in print. However, we ask that you pay attention to these simple guidelines. In a nutshell:
__label__fake 1. Do not include images, as in most cases we do not own the copyright.
__label__fake 2. Please do not edit the article.
__label__fake 3. Make sure you credit "Africa Check" in the byline and don't forget to mention that the article was originally published on africacheck.org.
__label__fake A fact-checker has rated your Facebook or Instagram post as “false”, “altered”, “partly false” or “missing context”. This could have serious consequences. What do you do?
__label__fake Click on our guide for the steps you should follow.
__label__fake Africa Check is a partner in
__label__fake Meta's third-party fact-checking programme
__label__fake to help stop the spread of false information on social media.
__label__fake The content we rate as “false” will be downgraded on Facebook and Instagram. This means fewer people will see it.
__label__fake You can also help identify false information on Facebook. This
__label__fake guide explains how.

__label__fake Africa Check values your trust and is committed to the responsible management, use and protection of personal information. See our privacy policy.
__label__fake 
__label__fake For democracy to function, public figures need to be held to account for what they say. The claims they make need to be checked, openly and impartially. Africa Check is an independent, non-partisan organisation which assesses claims made in the public arena using journalistic skills and evidence drawn from the latest online tools, readers, public sources and experts, sorting fact from fiction and publishing the results.
__label__fake Africa Check values your trust and is committed to the responsible management, use and protection of personal information. See our privacy policy.

__label__fake For democracy to function, public figures need to be held to account for what they say. The claims they make need to be checked, openly and impartially. Africa Check is an independent, non-partisan organisation which assesses claims made in the public arena using journalistic skills and evidence drawn from the latest online tools, readers, public sources and experts, sorting fact from fiction and publishing the results.
__label__fake Africa Check values your trust and is committed to the responsible management, use and protection of personal information. See our privacy policy.
__label__fake 
__label__fake © 2024 - Africa Check - All rights reserved.
__label__fake We will never charge you for verified, reliable information. Help us keep it that way by supporting our work.
__label__fake Africa Check values your trust and is committed to the responsible management, use and protection of personal information. See our privacy policy.
__label__fake Support independent fact-checking in Africa.
__label__fake We believe that everyone needs the facts.
__label__fake You can republish the text of this article free of charge, both online and in print. However, we ask that you pay attention to these simple guidelines. In a nutshell:
__label__fake 1. Do not include images, as in most cases we do not own the copyright.
__label__fake 2. Please do not edit the article.
__label__fake 3. Make sure you credit "Africa Check" in the byline and don't forget to mention that the article was originally published on africacheck.org.
__label__fake A fact-checker has rated your Facebook or Instagram post as “false”, “altered”, “partly false” or “missing context”. This could have serious consequences. What do you do?
__label__fake Click on our guide for the steps you should follow.
__label__fake Africa Check is a partner in
__label__fake Meta's third-party fact-checking programme
__label__fake to help stop the spread of false information on social media.
__label__fake The content we rate as “false” will be downgraded on Facebook and Instagram. This means fewer people will see it.
__label__fake You can also help identify false information on Facebook. This
__label__fake guide explains how.

__label__fake You can republish the text of this article free of charge, both online and in print. However, we ask that you pay attention to these simple guidelines. In a nutshell:
__label__fake 1. Do not include images, as in most cases we do not own the copyright.
__label__fake 2. Please do not edit the article.
__label__fake 3. Make sure you credit "Africa Check" in the byline and don't forget to mention that the article was originally published on africacheck.org.
__label__fake A fact-checker has rated your Facebook or Instagram post as “false”, “altered”, “partly false” or “missing context”. This could have serious consequences. What do you do?
__label__fake Click on our guide for the steps you should follow.
__label__fake Africa Check is a partner in
__label__fake Meta's third-party fact-checking programme
__label__fake to help stop the spread of false information on social media.
__label__fake The content we rate as “false” will be downgraded on Facebook and Instagram. This means fewer people will see it.
__label__fake You can also help identify false information on Facebook. This
__label__fake guide explains how.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Africa Check values your trust and is committed to the responsible management, use and protection of personal information. See our privacy policy.
__label__fake 
__label__fake For democracy to function, public figures need to be held to account for what they say. The claims they make need to be checked, openly and impartially. Africa Check is an independent, non-partisan organisation which assesses claims made in the public arena using journalistic skills and evidence drawn from the latest online tools, readers, public sources and experts, sorting fact from fiction and publishing the results.
__label__fake Africa Check values your trust and is committed to the responsible management, use and protection of personal information. See our privacy policy.
__label__fake 
__label__fake © 2024 - Africa Check - All rights reserved.
__label__fake We will never charge you for verified, reliable information. Help us keep it that way by supporting our work.

__label__fake Support independent fact-checking in Africa.
__label__fake 
__label__fake A post shared on Nestia.com titled “China prostitute with Coronavirus have to list out all the male clients to MOH” has been going viral on social media, and has garnered over 600 shares at time of publication.
__label__fake In the post is a Youtube video with the same title, and depicts a recording of a forwarded Whatsapp voice message.
__label__fake Here’s a word-for-word transcription and translation of the voice message, Singlish and all:
__label__fake “Wah this, this China lady works as a prostitute one ah, she stay Geylang one. Then ah, she got customer, they look for her ah, call for prostitute. Then now, she tell the Singapore government which customer which customer she sleep with, which hotel, then they must go and find them all. Jialat already. Now if their wives find out sure die. See lah, call prostitute some more lah.”
__label__fake Do note that throughout the voice message, there was no mention of COVID-19.
__label__fake Regardless, this has not stopped social media from hopping on the scandalous train.
__label__fake In a social media post by Facebook user Marwana Suleiman, she alleges that the Chinese prostitute in question was ‘Case 12’, but it is uncertain where she got that detail from.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Regardless, as a quick background, Case 12 was confirmed by MOH on 30 January along with Case 11 and Case 13. All three are female Chinese nationals and are not related to each other.
__label__fake Case 12 is a 37-year-old Chinese national from Wuhan who arrived in Singapore with her family on 22 January. She was asymptomatic during her flight to Singapore and subsequently developed symptoms on 26 January. She was confirmed to be infected with COVID-19 on 29 January at 11pm.
__label__fake Prior to hospital admission, she stayed at Village Hotel Sentosa, Hotel 81 Princess, and Home Suite View Hotel. She visited Orchard Road and Geylang and travelled by taxi.
__label__fake Where the links might have been drawn could be how on 31 January, Lianhe Wanbao reported that 2 men who were said to have close contact with Case 12 were being quarantined in their rooms at Home Suite View Hotel.
__label__fake When reporters visited the hotel on the night of 30 January, staff were seen wearing masks and said that they were not allowed to reveal the identities of the men.
__label__fake One staff who declined to be named mentioned that MOH had told them in a call to isolate the 2 men in their rooms because they were in close contact with Case 12. The staff added that MOH would call every hour to check that the men were still in their rooms.
__label__fake According to staff, Case 12 was not registered in the hotel’s system as a guest, but the 2 men had checked in on 27 January.
__label__fake When reporters went to Hotel 81 Princess, where Case 12 also stayed at, it was business as usual, and staff did not want to be interviewed.
__label__fake While the scenario does seem suggestive, there is no evidence or confirmation that Case 12 is a prostitute.
__label__fake The forbidden fruit is the juiciest
__label__fake As juicy as the news is, it’s actually no surprise that confirmed cases of COVID-19 are asked for a list of those they were in contact with.
__label__fake As of 18 February 2020, 12pm, MOH has identified 2,486 close contacts of COVID-19 cases who have been quarantined. Of these, 1,160 are currently quarantined, and 1,326 have completed their quarantine.
__label__fake However, it is still uncertain when the voice message was recorded, and if the information conveyed in the voice message is accurate in the first place. Most importantly, the voice message never mentioned anything about COVID-19.
__label__fake Therefore, the claim that the voice message is evidence that a Chinese prostitute with COVID-19 was asked provide a list of her male clients to MOH is likely false, due to the lack of context of what the individual in the voice message was actually referring to, and the lack of evidence that Case 12 was actually a prostitute.
__label__fake

__label__fake 
__label__fake Δdocument.getElementById( "ak_js_1" ).setAttribute( "value", ( new Date() ).getTime() );

__label__fake A post shared on Nestia.com titled “China prostitute with Coronavirus have to list out all the male clients to MOH” has been going viral on social media, and has garnered over 600 shares at time of publication.
__label__fake In the post is a Youtube video with the same title, and depicts a recording of a forwarded Whatsapp voice message.
__label__fake Here’s a word-for-word transcription and translation of the voice message, Singlish and all:
__label__fake “Wah this, this China lady works as a prostitute one ah, she stay Geylang one. Then ah, she got customer, they look for her ah, call for prostitute. Then now, she tell the Singapore government which customer which customer she sleep with, which hotel, then they must go and find them all. Jialat already. Now if their wives find out sure die. See lah, call prostitute some more lah.”
__label__fake Do note that throughout the voice message, there was no mention of COVID-19.
__label__fake Regardless, this has not stopped social media from hopping on the scandalous train.
__label__fake In a social media post by Facebook user Marwana Suleiman, she alleges that the Chinese prostitute in question was ‘Case 12’, but it is uncertain where she got that detail from.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Regardless, as a quick background, Case 12 was confirmed by MOH on 30 January along with Case 11 and Case 13. All three are female Chinese nationals and are not related to each other.
__label__fake Case 12 is a 37-year-old Chinese national from Wuhan who arrived in Singapore with her family on 22 January. She was asymptomatic during her flight to Singapore and subsequently developed symptoms on 26 January. She was confirmed to be infected with COVID-19 on 29 January at 11pm.
__label__fake Prior to hospital admission, she stayed at Village Hotel Sentosa, Hotel 81 Princess, and Home Suite View Hotel. She visited Orchard Road and Geylang and travelled by taxi.

__label__fake When reporters visited the hotel on the night of 30 January, staff were seen wearing masks and said that they were not allowed to reveal the identities of the men.
__label__fake One staff who declined to be named mentioned that MOH had told them in a call to isolate the 2 men in their rooms because they were in close contact with Case 12. The staff added that MOH would call every hour to check that the men were still in their rooms.
__label__fake According to staff, Case 12 was not registered in the hotel’s system as a guest, but the 2 men had checked in on 27 January.
__label__fake When reporters went to Hotel 81 Princess, where Case 12 also stayed at, it was business as usual, and staff did not want to be interviewed.
__label__fake While the scenario does seem suggestive, there is no evidence or confirmation that Case 12 is a prostitute.
__label__fake The forbidden fruit is the juiciest
__label__fake As juicy as the news is, it’s actually no surprise that confirmed cases of COVID-19 are asked for a list of those they were in contact with.
__label__fake As of 18 February 2020, 12pm, MOH has identified 2,486 close contacts of COVID-19 cases who have been quarantined. Of these, 1,160 are currently quarantined, and 1,326 have completed their quarantine.
__label__fake However, it is still uncertain when the voice message was recorded, and if the information conveyed in the voice message is accurate in the first place. Most importantly, the voice message never mentioned anything about COVID-19.

__label__fake 
__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.
__label__fake

__label__fake Δdocument.getElementById( "ak_js_3" ).setAttribute( "value", ( new Date() ).getTime() );
__label__fake © 2024 Black Dot Research.
__label__fake 
__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Save my name, email, and website in this browser for the next time I comment.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Δdocument.getElementById( "ak_js_1" ).setAttribute( "value", ( new Date() ).getTime() );

__label__fake © 2024 Black Dot Research.
__label__fake 
__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.

__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.

__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.

__label__fake 
__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.

__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.

__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Save my name, email, and website in this browser for the next time I comment.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Δdocument.getElementById( "ak_js_1" ).setAttribute( "value", ( new Date() ).getTime() );

__label__fake #06-12 SINGAPORE 159929

__label__fake © 2024 Black Dot Research.
__label__fake 
__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Save my name, email, and website in this browser for the next time I comment.

__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.

__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.

__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.
