__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.

__label__fake +65 6517 0627

__label__fake 
__label__fake Email address

__label__fake Δdocument.getElementById( "ak_js_3" ).setAttribute( "value", ( new Date() ).getTime() );
__label__fake © 2024 Black Dot Research.
__label__fake 
__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Save my name, email, and website in this browser for the next time I comment.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Δdocument.getElementById( "ak_js_1" ).setAttribute( "value", ( new Date() ).getTime() );

__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.

__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.

__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.

__label__fake 
__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.
__label__fake

__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.

__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.
__label__fake

__label__fake Δdocument.getElementById( "ak_js_1" ).setAttribute( "value", ( new Date() ).getTime() );

__label__fake © 2024 Black Dot Research.
__label__fake 
__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.
__label__fake

__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.

__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.

__label__fake 
__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.

__label__fake 
__label__fake While our previous article on the Wuhan virus covered messages that have spread through WhatsApp and social media, this article looks into the ‘remedies’ and ‘cures’ that have emerged.
__label__fake Here are a few of them.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake According to this message, the cure for the Wuhan virus is as simple as boiling 8 cloves of garlic in 7 cups of water. It also cited that the information came from an organisation called ‘International Entrepreneurs Federation’.
__label__fake However, a quick check on the URL in the message doesn’t show any sign of the ‘remedy’ mentioned above. In fact, all the page contains are embedded videos about the Wuhan virus from reputable news sources.
__label__fake It’s not surprising, though, that some would think that there is some truth in this claim and forward the message without doing a check.
__label__fake Garlic has long been used in home remedies for ailments like coughs and colds, and according to a study, have been thought to be able “reduce the risk for cardiovascular diseases, have anti-tumor and anti-microbial effects, and show benefit on high blood glucose concentration”.
__label__fake The same study acknowledges, though, that “due to some issues, such as methodological inadequacies, small sample sizes, lack of information regarding dose rationale, variation between efficacy and effectiveness trials, the absence of a placebo comparator, or lack of control groups”, more trials and research is needed to confirm the beneficial effects of garlic in various diseases.
__label__fake Another article which delves into a few studies on the health benefits of garlic,  also notes that “only some of these uses are backed by research”.
__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This other message suggests that individuals should keep their throats moist and “not let [their] throat dry up” in order to prevent infection.
__label__fake It goes on to warn that “once your membrane in your throat is dried, the virus will invade into (sic) your body within 10 mins” and even gives a recommended amount of water to drink for adults and children.
__label__fake While there are definitely benefits in staying hydrated, there is no proof that keeping your throat moist helps to prevent infection.
__label__fake A health advisory issued by the World Health Organization has listed several ways of how individuals can reduce their risk of infection:
__label__fake Source: WHO website
__label__fake As seen from the attached infographic, there is nothing about drinking a certain amount of water and/or staying hydrated being mentioned.
__label__fake Interestingly enough, this message was actually addressed by the Ministry of Health earlier this month. Then, MOH had come out to debunk the claim, stating that “keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza”.
__label__fake We therefore rate that while the claim doesn’t offer terrible advice, it helping to prevent infection is false.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Another recommendation the message made was that individuals “not go to crowded places, wear mask as needed especially in train or public transportation [and] avoid fried or spicy food and load up vitamin C” until the end of March 2020, which suggests that there’s a certain ‘end date’ to the virus.
__label__fake Currently, it’s impossible to tell when a cure for the Wuhan virus would emerge and subsequently, when the crisis would end. Therefore the suggestion that individuals engage in these practices “until the end of March 2020” is misleading and unproven.
__label__fake Source: WhatsApp
__label__fake This message goes so far as to suggest that a cure has already been found.
__label__fake Chock-full of scientific jargon, it truly embodies the saying ‘if you can’t convince them, confuse them’.
__label__fake At time of publication, a global search for the cure is still ongoing, although China is currently using AbbVie Inc.’s HIV drugs as an ad-hoc treatment for pneumonia caused by the coronavirus.
__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.
__label__fake The claim that a cure for the Wuhan virus is therefore false.

__label__fake Regardless, the claim that this garlic water concoction helps individuals to “recover” from the Wuhan virus is unproven, because at time of publication, the search for a cure is still ongoing.

__label__fake However, it is important to note that there is still “not yet any effective anti-viral drug”.

__label__fake Fact Crescendo Sri Lanka English | The leading fact-checking website
__label__fake The Fact Behind Every News!
__label__fake 2019-nCoV, a respiratory virus first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan, on the eve of 2020 has now infected thousands of Chinese citizens and has spread to a number of other countries. The rapidly spreading virus, which causes pneumonia-like symptoms, has been declared as a global emergency with the death toll rising above 200.
__label__fake Chinese Authorities were quick to respond to the spread of the virus. They locked down Wuhan, the center of the outbreak and Chinese medical research institutions as well as the research facilities have been working round the clock to find  a cure to the deadly virus. On social media, number of posts were shared admiring the marvel of Chinese building a new hospital to treat the patients in just 6 days in Wuhan city.
__label__fake We observed a post published by Facebook page “Think Moment”, captioned “තමන්ගේ මිනිස්සු ‌වෙනුවෙන්” shared two images, one of a construction site and another image of completed building. The post claims that the two pictures show the transformation of empty land being levelled by JCB cranes into a grand multispecialty hospital  in just two days!
__label__fake Number of similar posts are getting shared and given below is a website making the same claim with the headline reading, “Chinese complete and declare open the proposed 06 day hospital in 2 days”
__label__fake Within a short span of time, these posts and articles were shared multiple times with many commending the ingenuity of Chinese.  Many Facebook users reacted with disbelief and accused admins for misleading readers. Hence, we decided to find out the truth. Let us see whether this hard to believe news, a fact or a hoax.
__label__fake Fact Check.
__label__fake We did a google reverse image search of the image of hospital building and came across number of news reports as shown below.
__label__fake Google Reverse Image Search Link
__label__fake Our attention was drawn to the “DailyMail” report captioned “China’s first coronavirus hospital Opens after workers and volunteers spend two days converting an empty building into a 1,000-bed medical center as the global death toll hits 133” published on the 29th of January.
__label__fake The report with images on how they converted the building within 2 days into a 1000 bed emergency facility went on to state that, “The hospital building in the city’s Huangzhou District was originally built as a new branch of Huanggang Central Hospital and was expected to open in May. But on Friday, the local authority ordered the complete but empty building to be used for treating coronavirus patients only and began preparations on Saturday.”
__label__fake We checked news reports for latest updates on the hospital proposed to be constructed in 6 days. China’s official news agency Xinhua published photos of the construction site in Huoshenshan, where the proposed hospital.
__label__fake State owned International English-language news channel CGTN (China Global Television Network), formerly known as CCTV-9 and CCTV News, is broadcasting a 24 hour live feed of the construction site of Huoshenshan Hospital.
__label__fake Live: Construction of #Wuhan prefab hospitals for #coronavirus patients underway https://t.co/2Sgvn52GF3
__label__fake Below is a time-lapse video posted by Guardian News capturing areal views of Wuhan hospital construction
__label__fake We did a reverse image search of the construction site images of the first claim to ascertain that they were from the Huoshenshan Hospital and found that they were indeed associated with the hospital which was being built from scratch. The article “Wuhan’s new coronavirus hospital explained” from CGTN explains how this ambitious project is taking shape. The project is based on the Xiaotangshan model’ which played a crucial role in China’s battle against SARS 17 years ago.
__label__fake Wuhan Huoshenshan Hospital is due to open on February 3rd, and the Leishenshan Hospital, which is a similar hospital being built to combat the deadly virus due to open on February 5th.
__label__fake Conclusion.
__label__fake Our fact check reveals that the newly opened hospital is an extended wing of Huanggang Central Hospital, scheduled to open in May 2020. A dedicated work force made the empty building into a fully operational hospital within two days, which was mistaken as the Huoshenshan Hospital proposed to be constructed in 6 days.  Huoshenshan hospital is still under construction and is expected to open to the patients on 3rd  day of February.
__label__fake Title:China didn’t construct a Hospital in just 2 days instead of the proposed 6 days. Here’s the truth…
__label__fake Result: False
__label__fake Your email address will not be published. Required fields are marked *

__label__fake Por Carmen Quintela //
__label__fake julio 8, 2020 //
__label__fake En redes sociales circula un video en el que se asegura que un ataúd llegó vacío a un entierro en Sololá. El Ministerio de Salud aclara que es falso, que personal de la cartera entregó el cadáver de un joven en una bolsa especial dentro del ataúd luego de seguir los protocolos y que el cuerpo fue enterrado.
__label__fake [Suscríbete a El Correo de Ocote para no perderte nuestras historias]
__label__fake Circula en redes sociales un video de poco más de dos minutos en el que puede verse como unas personas con Equipo de Protección Individual abren una ambulancia en la que se encuentra un ataúd.
__label__fake En el video llega a observar cómo un grupo grande de personas parece esperar el ataúd, lo rodea y lo abre. Dentro se ve una bolsa blanca, cerrada, que alguien abre y se descubre algo negro en su interior. No se distingue bien si es otra bolsa o un espacio vacío.
__label__fake Sobre el video aparece escrito “Junio 2020” y “Sololá, ataúd vacío sin muerto”.
__label__fake Una usuaria nos envió el video al Twitter de Fáctica y nos pidió verificarlo.
__label__fake Se consultó a Julia Barreda, vocera del Ministerio de Salud Pública y Asistencia Social (MSPAS) acerca de la veracidad del video. La comunicadora explicó que “de acuerdo con el Área de Salud de Sololá, el fallecido es un joven de una comunidad del departamento que estaba enfermo. Llamaron al servicio de salud, se fue a traer al paciente y falleció en la ambulancia. Se hizo el acta y todo lo del protocolo”.
__label__fake Al llegar al cementerio, indicó Barreda, la comunidad comenzó a decir que no había fallecido por COVID-19 y a pedir que no lo enterraran. “Hubo cierta resistencia, querían incluso abrir la bolsa. Al final se solucionó y lo enterraron”.
__label__fake “Si se observa detenidamente el vídeo, se puede ver cuando intentan abrir el zíper de la bolsa color blanco —añadió—. Hay un protocolo establecido para las inhumaciones. El cuerpo es colocado en una bolsa especial y por la seguridad de los familiares no debe abrirse y luego colocarse en el ataúd, como parte de los lineamientos para manejo de cadáveres”.
__label__fake La hipoxia es una condición que implica los tejidos no se oxigenan adecuadamente. Las probabilidades de que el uso de mascarilla la provoque, como...
__label__fake Las imágenes que aseguran una reapertura inminente de bares, iglesias o colegios, no son del Gobierno, aseguran fuentes oficiales.
__label__fake Ha circulado en redes sociales una imagen atribuida al Comité Coordinador de Asociaciones Agrícolas, Comerciales, Industriales y Financieras (Cacif) en la que se convoca...
__label__fake mágenes sobre un supuesto “Escuadrón de Oriente” en Jutiapa, corresponden a los patrulleros de Bárcenas, Villa Nueva.

__label__fake · info@agenciaocote.com ·

__label__fake 8月16日，针对“一些微信群流传博白县发现1名新冠肺炎确诊病例密切接触者”，博白县新型冠状病毒肺炎疫情防控工作领导小组指挥部发布通报：
__label__fake 近日，一些微信群流传博白县发现1名新冠肺炎确诊病例密切接触者。经核查，系我县居民刘某海从深圳市某鲜生超市辞职回到博白。博白县疾病预防控制中心对刘某海及其家人进行体温测量，体温均正常，无咳嗽、咽痛等相关症状。
__label__fake 经玉林市疾病预防控制中心与博白县疾病预防控制中心新冠病毒核酸检测均为阴性。

__label__fake Bolivia Verifica es un medio digital independiente, sin fines de lucro ni tendencia política que tiene como objetivo verificar noticias y el discurso público para luchar contra la desinformación y mejorar la participación democrática.
__label__fake Somos un medio digital independiente sin fines de lucro ni tendencia política que se dedica a la verificación de noticias falsas (fake news) y del discurso público para luchar contra la desinformación y mejorar la participación democrática. Chatbot Olivia +591 62352290.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Bolivia Verifica
__label__fake 
__label__fake Por las redes sociales circula un video en el que se ve a un paciente esforzándose por respirar. En una cadena de WhatsApp se dijo que era del oriente boliviano. “Hola, me mandó una amiga, indican que es un muchacho de sta cruz que contrajo el coronavirus (sic)”. Pero, de acuerdo al rastreo realizado, este video circuló en  Colombia horas antes de que llegue a Bolivia.
__label__fake 
__label__fake El portal de noticias de Colombia “Hoy Diario del Magdalena” informó este 19 de marzo de 2020 que un joven se apersonó de emergencia al “Hospital de Fundación” con problemas respiratorios. Por los síntomas y comportamiento, se le hizo la prueba para detectar si tenía el Covid-19. El resultado salió negativo, pero sí se le diagnosticó Infección Respiratoria Aguda.
__label__fake “El coordinador Médico, del hospital San Rafael, doctor Rodolfo De la Valle, dijo que paciente que sospechaba tener coronavirus, al ser valorado por galenos de la entidad, le diagnosticaron una Infección Respiratoria Aguda (ira) y por ende se le mandó tratamiento dándosele de alta (sic)”, se lee en la noticia del Diario del Magdalena.
__label__fake 
__label__fake El 18 de marzo de este año, el Hospital Departamental San Rafael de Fundación aclaró a través de un comunicado que en sus instalaciones no cuenta con ningún infectado con el coronavirus. Y que cuentan con los recursos para atender a una persona que tenga en Covid-19.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Para respaldar este comunicado, en las redes sociales de ese nosocomio publicaron un video aclarando que la persona que ingreso al Hospital tiene un caso de Infección Aguda Respiratoria y no así de coronavirus.
__label__fake 
__label__fake ¿Cómo podemos descartar que el video no es un caso cruceño?
__label__fake Porque en el video se ve a una persona de sexo masculino bastante joven. De los casos reportados en el departamento de Santa Cruz, tres están en centros médicos y dos en sus respectivos domicilios. A continuación te dejamos una síntesis de los 5 casos confirmados hasta el 20 de marzo de 2020 en el departamento oriental:
__label__fake Bolivia Verifica te aconseja no compartir imágenes o videos con contenido sensible. Nos encontramos en una situación de susceptibilidad informática y por lo mismo debemos acudir a medios oficiales que brinden noticias veraces.
__label__fake Tu dirección de correo electrónico no será publicada. Los campos obligatorios están marcados con *
__label__fake Comentario *
__label__fake Nombre
__label__fake Correo electrónico
__label__fake Web
__label__fake 
__label__fake 
__label__fake 
__label__fake 
__label__fake Teléfono: (591 2) 2414687Whatsapp: (+591) 62535868Correo: info@boliviaverifica.bo
__label__fake 
__label__fake Dirección: Calle Miguel de Cervantes # 2770 (entre Vincenti y Méndez Arcos), zona Sopocachi, ciudad La Paz – Bolivia (Ver mapa)
__label__fake 
__label__fake Fecha:
__label__fake Comparte:
__label__fake Es falso que las autoridades de Nuevo León, en México, hayan instruido normas para prohibir el consumo y venta de bebidas alcohólicas por la contingencia de COVID-19.
__label__fake En WhatsApp y redes sociales comenzó a circular una imagen alterada en donde se afirma que el Gobierno de Nuevo León dictó Ley Seca, es decir prohibición de bebidas alcohólicas, ante la emergencia sanitaria por el nuevo coronavirus.
__label__fake En una búsqueda hecha en el portal del medio de comunicación El Norte, no es posible encontrar la nota: “Confirman Ley Seca en NL a partir del Jueves 26 por tiempo indefinido”.
__label__fake La imagen fue modificada de una nota original que emitió el medio de comunicación para informar sobre nuevos casos de COVID-19 el 13 de marzo de 2020.
__label__fake El pase de diapositivas requiere JavaScript.
__label__fake Hasta el 23 de marzo de 2020, el gobierno estatal no ha instruido alguna notificación relacionada con el tema e incluso confirmó en sus redes sociales que se trataba de una foto falsa.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Acá te dejamos 10 claves para detectar desinformación  www.verificado.com.mx/10_claves_fakenews/
__label__fake 
__label__fake Somos un medio de comunicación especializado en el Fact Checking o verificación de hechos; se refiere a la labor de confirmar y comprobar hechos y datos.

__label__fake Fecha:
__label__fake Comparte:
__label__fake Es falso que las autoridades de Nuevo León, en México, hayan instruido normas para prohibir el consumo y venta de bebidas alcohólicas por la contingencia de COVID-19.
__label__fake En WhatsApp y redes sociales comenzó a circular una imagen alterada en donde se afirma que el Gobierno de Nuevo León dictó Ley Seca, es decir prohibición de bebidas alcohólicas, ante la emergencia sanitaria por el nuevo coronavirus.
__label__fake En una búsqueda hecha en el portal del medio de comunicación El Norte, no es posible encontrar la nota: “Confirman Ley Seca en NL a partir del Jueves 26 por tiempo indefinido”.
__label__fake La imagen fue modificada de una nota original que emitió el medio de comunicación para informar sobre nuevos casos de COVID-19 el 13 de marzo de 2020.
__label__fake El pase de diapositivas requiere JavaScript.
__label__fake Hasta el 23 de marzo de 2020, el gobierno estatal no ha instruido alguna notificación relacionada con el tema e incluso confirmó en sus redes sociales que se trataba de una foto falsa.
__label__fake 
__label__fake Acá te dejamos 10 claves para detectar desinformación  www.verificado.com.mx/10_claves_fakenews/
__label__fake 
__label__fake Somos un medio de comunicación especializado en el Fact Checking o verificación de hechos; se refiere a la labor de confirmar y comprobar hechos y datos.
__label__fake © Verificado 2023 - Te conviene saber más
__label__fake The claims were published here on Instagram on August 3, 2020. The post has received more than 290 likes.
__label__fake The text in the image reads in part: “The Virology Journal - the official publication of Dr. Fauci's National Institutes of Health - published what is now a blockbuster article on August 22, 2005, under the heading - get ready for this - ‘Chloroquine is a potion of SARS coronavirus infection and spread.’
__label__fake “This means, of course, that Dr. Fauci has known for 15 years that chloroquine and its even milder hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) will not only treat a current case of coronavirus (‘therapeutic’) but prevent future cases ('prophylactic’). So HCQ functions as both a cure and a vaccine.”
__label__fake The caption of the Instagram post states: “ALL THOSE BLOCKING INFORMATION ON HCQ ARE COMMITTING GENOCIDE INCLUDING FAUCI, DAN ANDREWS AND THE AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT.”
__label__fake Dr. Anthony Fauci has been the director of National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) under the US Department of Health and Human Services’ National Institutes of Health (NIH) since 1984.
__label__fake Chloroquine (CQ) is a malaria and amebiasis drug. Hydroxychloroquine (HCQ), a less toxic metabolite of chloroquine, is used to treat rheumatic diseases, according to this 2020 study.
__label__fake The claims were also shared on Facebook here, here, here and here; on Twitter here, here, here and here; and on various websites here and here.
__label__fake The claims, however, are false.
__label__fake 2005 study
__label__fake The study cited in the misleading post is this 2005 paper titled “Chloroquine is a potent inhibitor of SARS coronavirus infection and spread”. It was published following the 2003 outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), an infectious disease caused by a SARS-associated coronavirus, known as SARS-CoV.
__label__fake The paper states in part: “Chloroquine is effective in preventing the spread of SARS CoV in cell culture. Favorable inhibition of virus spread was observed when the cells were either treated with chloroquine prior to or after SARS CoV infection. In addition, the indirect immunofluorescence assay described herein represents a simple and rapid method for screening SARS-CoV antiviral compounds.”
__label__fake The study adds that all experiments were conducted “extracellularly” -- in a controlled environment outside of a living organism, and not on humans or other animals.
__label__fake In response to the misleading posts, Dr. Eric Bergeron of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), who co-wrote the 2005 paper, said: "This is totally absurd."
__label__fake “This paper only shows that chloroquine works in cell culture experiments, later studies in mice suggested that chloroquine was not effective against SARS-CoV," he said in an email on August 5.
__label__fake “Our results published suggested that chloroquine should be considered in human trials but trials demonstrated that it is ineffective against SARS-CoV-2 (which causes COVID-19). This is very common, many drugs show efficacy in cell culture but no clinical benefit. This is what people should care about: no clinical benefit. We treated cells in culture not humans.”
__label__fake Fauci claim
__label__fake The 2005 paper was published in the Virology Journal, an “open access, peer reviewed journal that considers articles on all aspects of virology, including research on the viruses of animals, plants and microbes,” according to information on its website here.
__label__fake The Journal belongs to the UK for-profit science publisher BioMed Central Company, which is a part of the British-German academic publishing company Springer Nature. It is not associated with Dr. Fauci or the NIH as stated in the misleading claim.
__label__fake A spokesperson for NIAID told AFP in an email dated August 5: “Dr. Fauci has previously stated that there is a lack of good evidence from randomized placebo-controlled trials to indicate that hydroxychloroquine is an effective therapeutic for COVID-19. The 2005 paper you are referring to was a cell-culture experiment with a different virus than SARS-CoV-2, and the study was conducted by CDC investigators. Virology Journal is published by BMC, part of Springer-Nature.”
__label__fake Fauci has become a target of COVID-19 misinformation as the novel coronavirus continues to spread globally, AFP reported here.
__label__fake 'No cure'
__label__fake In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, the debate over hydroxychloroquine has become politically charged. Leaders including US President Donald Trump and some fellow US conservatives have voiced strong support for the drug as a treatment for the novel coronavirus, AFP reported here.
__label__fake As of August 7, 2020, the WHO states on its website that “there is currently no proof that hydroxychloroquine or any other drug can cure or prevent COVID-19” and that “the misuse of hydroxychloroquine can cause serious side effects and illness and even lead to death.” It also ruled out the use of HCQ a treatment for hospitalised COVID-19 patients since “hydroxychloroquine does not result in the reduction of mortality of hospitalised COVID-19 patients, when compared with standard of care,” according to this June 17 announcement.
__label__fake Similarly on June 15, the US Food & Drug Administration (FDA) revoked the emergency use authorization (EUA) to use HCQ and CQ to treat COVID-19. “We made this determination based on recent results from a large, randomized clinical trial in hospitalized patients that found these medicines showed no benefit for decreasing the likelihood of death or speeding recovery,” the FDA states here.
__label__fake AFP previously debunked false claims that HCQ can cure COVID-19 here and here.

The 2005 paper you are referring to was a cell-culture experiment with a different virus than SARS-CoV-2, and the study was conducted by CDC investigators.
